Text:
This is the tale of a certain New Year's day when
Alpha visited a therianthrope shrine to obtain some
kagami rice cakes...

Visiting a shrine on New Year's day requires
proper attire...

This is a therianthrope shrine, though, so my
concepts of etiquette and formality may not
apply.
Who can I turn to at a time like this...

I look over the Seven Shadows here in the room
with me.
Shrine time, shrine time! Time to go to the shrine!

There is Delta, but... No. Even among therianthropes
there are different customs depending on where one
goes.

Gamma, Epsilon. I want to choose something appropriate
to wear to the shrine. Can you help?
Me? Not that I mind, but...

I have never heard anything about a shrine that has
kagami rice cakes...

Neither of them seem to have much faith in their
knowledge of therianthrope attire.

There's no need to look so worried. I'm sure you will
both be of great help.

After all, there's no one in the Seven Shadows
as on-point as you two when it comes to design,
dress codes, and fashion, right?
Yes, well...that is part of my job.

Gamma is referring to her other identity as "Luna",
the director of Mitsugoshi.

And a pianist will be a laughingstock if she doesn't
know how to dress for the occasion, wherever it
may be.

Epsilon, too, performs as "Shiron", an up-and-coming
pianist and composer. The two of them are both
wonderful sources of advice.
I'll leave my attire and Deltaâ€™s clothes to you.
That is an honor...! And quite a lot of pressure!

To start, is it alright if I bring Nu into the
conversation?

Yes, good idea. As our resident disguise makeup
specialist, she should likely have some good tips.

And thus our meeting about what to wear
to the shrine begins...
We decide upon Delta's outfit almost immediately.

The reason being that Mitsugoshi has almost no
long-sleeved kimono capable of accommodating
therianthrope tails available on short notice.

I failed to consider that...! I will make sure we have
not just kimono, but a full line of apparel available
for therianthropes!
Well, I'll go get Lady Delta dressed in this kimono.

With the newly-decided design in hand, Nu goes
to see to Delta in the other room.

I wonder if she's capable of dressing Delta on
her own?

Once we get your outfit sorted, I believe it might be
best if I go assist her.

I had been thinking the exact same thing. I nod and
ask her to see to it.

Please, would you be so kind? I'm almost certain
that girl will make a fuss.

Therianthropes, and that girl in particular, grow very
attached to things they like. So she is likely to gripe
about these unfamiliar clothes being difficult to move
about in.

As you wish. Now if you'd like to look through this
catalog...
Gamma pulls out a kimono catalog from Mitsugoshi.

Long, mid-length, short... Though we call them all long-
sleeve kimono, it seems there are many varieties of
sleeves.

Ah, so the last few pages show you how to wear
a kimono. Hmm, this is very interesting.

I look at the pages that had caught her attention,
and see an illustration of a woman in a kimono
that bares her shoulders.

This one exposes a lot of skin and seems like it'd be
good for catching people's eyes.

Epsilon, the purpose of our visit is kagami rice
cakes, not to make a scene.

Oh, that's right... And anyway, this style would be
much too titillating if someone of your caliber
wore it, Lady Alpha...!

The style of how it is worn is important, yes,
but let's decide upon the type of kimono first.

Ever the saleswoman, Gamma picks up the catalog
and refocuses everyone on the matter at hand.

The main difference between the varieties is
determined by the length of the sleeves.

The longest has sleeves that drape almost to
the ground, and is sometimes used in nuptials.

So it's like a wedding dress... That might be too
formal.

I think you might actually stand out in the wrong way
for trying too hard.

Then in the middle we have your classic long-sleeved
kimono. This is my personal recommendation.

I like that you can see the ankles. That would really
show off those long legs of yours.

This is pretty close to the image I had. I feel like
this would be a safe choice.

Indeed. But for the sake of explanation, we also
have the variety with the shortest sleeves.

This one would be the easiest to move about in...
In fact, I suspect this is what Delta is wearing.

Indeed, it is. But for you, I would say the middle
length is best.
Alright, then. Let's go with that.

Now that the variety of kimono is settled, it is
time to try it on...or apparently not.
Now it's time to choose the pattern of the kimono.

As she speaks, Gamma opens the catalog to pages
listing many distinctive patterns.

Even with flowers, there are several options,
such as cherry blossoms or roses.

And each pattern has its own meaning. Cherry blossoms
represent new ventures, while chestnut burrs depict
bounding happiness.

I see there are various color combinations as well...
Fashion is quite involved.
Never fear, Lady Alpha. That's what we're here for.

That's right. In your case, Lady Alpha, I think this
motif with this pattern and this color wouldâ€”

But that would wreck the effect produced by the
complimentary colors, so for a hue, I suggestâ€”

Gamma and Epsilon launch into a discussion full of
specialized terminology that I struggle to make heads
or tails of.

I knew I'd made the right choice asking them for
help. They know much more than I ever could...

All done. Now to have your slime bodysuit recreate
the completed design.
So our suits can reproduce patterns and colors...

In the meantime, Gamma goes to help Nu, as Delta has
apparently proved to be a bit of a handful.

I want to go see if everything is all right, but
Epsilon's slime kimono fitting requires that I
stay still.

Thank you, Gamma, Epsilon. This kimono makes me
feel graceful, yet also brightens my heart... It's a
wonderful ensemble.

I'm grateful to hear you say so, Lady Alpha.
It's all thanks to you allowing me to choose
the pattern I thought would suit you best.

That's you, Lady Alpha. But to tell you the truth,
we were only just barely able to reproduce
your kimono. They're so complex in both make
and pattern...

Yes, even just walking a little means... I need to
think of how the sleeves are meant to move,
change the color and patternâ€”

Partly because of the unfamiliarity of the design,
I find it difficult to control my slime suit.
Perhaps...like this?

Phew, looks like we've gotten the fit rightâ€”
Lady Alpha! Your legs! Theyâ€™reâ€”
Huh?

I look down at the legs in question, and see that
the slime is beginning to peel off.

I was so focused on controlling my sleeves that I
hadn't paid the rest of the suit any thought.

So even Lady Alpha's magic control wavers at times.
That means, one weak moment and...
One weak moment and what?

Lady Alpha's slime suit will come apart in the middle
of the crowd of shrine-goers, leaving her as naked
as the day she was born.
Wh-Why, we can't have that!

Indeed, that would create quite the scene. And once
in the nude, we would most likely be thrown off the
premises without any kagami rice cakes.

Oh, but I was speaking more of the embarrassment
that would cause...
And of course there is that, yes.

...All this tells me that it might be best to forgo
a slime suit reproduction this time around.

And while I think it highly unlikely, if by chance
there was a battle at the shrine, this amount of
magic control would prevent me from reacting
as needed.

True, even I would find it difficult to maintain
that outfit during combat.

Well then, I'll have the staff at Mitsugoshi prepare
a real kimono. We'll save the stitchery for the
details so that it will be ready in time.
Yes, please do.

And thatâ€™s how Delta and I paid a visit to the
therianthrope shrine wearing genuine kimono.
